title: How to Fix a Sagging Closet Rod

steps.headline: Measure your current closet rod's diameter, and how far it hangs away from the wall.
steps.description: The easiest way to do the latter is to measure how long the current brackets are.

steps.headline: Locate a stud near the center of the closet rod, or two studs equidistant to the center, with a stud finder.
steps.description: If you don't have a stud finder, tap gently across the wall. The drywall will sound hollow between studs, and firmer as you're knocking over the stud itself.

steps.headline: Remove all the clothing from the rod.
steps.description: Hold the new brackets in place over the studs, supporting the rod so it lays flat, and mark the location of the mounting holes on the drywall with a pencil.

steps.headline: Drill the appropriate starting holes for the mounting hardware that came with your new closet bracket or brackets.
steps.description: Remove the rod and screw-mount the new brackets in place.

steps.headline: Drop the closet rod back into place.
steps.description: The new brackets will help support it along its length, preventing or at least reducing sag.

steps.headline: Measure how high the bottom edge of the closet rod hangs from the floor at the end points, where it doesn't sag at all.
Mark this distance on a wooden 1 3/8-inch (3.5 cm) or thicker dowel.
Use the spade bit to bore a hole through the dowel.
steps.description: The bottom edge of the hole should intersect the mark you just made.

steps.headline: Saw straight through the hole you just bored, one-quarter to one-half of the way up from the bottom.
steps.description: This leaves a cylinder-shaped socket in the top end of the dowel.

steps.headline: Place the dowel beneath the center of the closet rod to prop up the sagging middle.
